title: 106_s652
content:
The "Safety and Health Whistleblower Protection Act" amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to include reporting injuries, illnesses, or unsafe conditions. It also prohibits discrimination against employees who take such actions. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION OF DISCRIMINATION.

Amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act to protect employees from discrimination for refusing duties that may cause serious harm. Requires communication of perceived danger to the employer.

SEC. 4. PROCEDURE. Section 11(c) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to allow employees to file a complaint within 180 days if they believe they have been discriminated against. The Secretary will investigate complaints within 90 days and notify both the complainant and the accused party. The Secretary will investigate complaints of discrimination within 90 days. If a violation is found, a preliminary order providing relief will be issued. The accused party or complainant can file objections within 30 days and request a hearing. Failure to request a hearing promptly will not stay the preliminary order. If the Secretary does not issue findings within 90 days of investigating discrimination complaints, a hearing can be requested by the employee. The hearing will be conducted by an administrative law judge, and a final order must be issued within 120 days of the recommended decision. Legal burdens of proof under section 1221 of title 5, United States Code, will apply to adjudicate violations. If a violation of paragraph (1) or (2) is found in response to a complaint, the Secretary can order corrective actions, reinstatement with compensation, compensatory and exemplary damages. The Secretary may also assess a sum against the violator. The Secretary can order corrective actions, reinstatement with compensation, compensatory and exemplary damages for violations. The person against whom the order is issued may be required to pay all costs and expenses incurred by the complainant. Review of the final order can be sought before the United States court of appeals within 60 days. The petition for review must be filed within 60 days of the Secretary's order issuance, in accordance with chapter 7 of title 5, US Code. Orders subject to review are not judicially reviewable in criminal or civil proceedings. Failure to comply with an order may result in a civil action filed in the district court for enforcement. The court may grant additional relief as appropriate. The court has jurisdiction to grant additional relief in cases of noncompliance. The amendments to the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 include a provision related to the history of violations. The effective date for these changes will be 90 days after the enactment of the Act.
